review.title: Linguistic Harbingers of Betrayal: A Case Study on an Online Strategy Game
review.abstract: Interpersonal relations are fickle, with close friendships often dissolving into enmity. In this work, we explore linguistic cues that presage such transitions by studying dyadic interactions in an online strategy game where players form alliances and break those alliances through betrayal. We characterize friendships that are unlikely to last and examine temporal patterns that foretell betrayal.

metadata.title: Linguistic Harbingers of Betrayal: A Case Study on an Online Strategy Game

sections.text: We reveal that subtle signs of imminent betrayal are encoded in the conversation patterns of the dyad, even if the victim is unaware of the fate of the relationship. In particular, we find that lasting friendships have a form of equilibrium manifested through language. In contrast, sudden changes in the equilibrium of certain conversation traits - such as positive feelings, courtesy, or a focus on planning the future - signal an imminent betrayal.

sections.heading: 2 Communication and Conflict in Diplomacy
sections.text: A diplomatic game begins in 1901 with players posing as the European powers on the eve of the First World War: England, Germany, France, Russia, Austria, Italy and the Ottoman Empire. The aim of the game (like other war games such as Risk or Axis & Allies) is to conquer all the territories on the board (Figure 1). The games are divided into years from 1901 and each year is divided into two seasons - Spring and Autumn. Each season consists of two alternating phases: Diplomacy - the players communicate to develop strategies - and Commands - the players submit their moves for the season. Seasons are therefore the most important unit of the season.

sections.heading: 2.1 Movement, Orders, and Battles
sections.text: On the playing field, each player can operate one unit for each city he or she controls, and during each turn, these pieces have the ability to move to neighboring territory. What makes diplomacy unique is that all players submit their written (or electronic) commands; these commands are executed simultaneously; and there is no randomness (e.g. dice). Thus, the outcome of the game depends only on the communication, cooperation, and movement of the players. If two units are in the same territory, this implies a battle. Whoever wins the battle is decided purely on the basis of numerical superiority (ties go to defenders). Instead of moving, one unit can support another unit; large armies can be created through intricate support networks; the side with the largest army wins the battle.The process of supporting one unit is therefore crucial both for a successful attack and for a successful defense. Often, an individual player lacks the support to support his or her attacks sufficiently, and therefore needs the help of others.

sections.heading: 2.2 Communication
sections.text: In the diplomatic phase of the game, players talk to each other. These conversations are either public or - more typically - one-to-one. Conversations include greetings, off-game discussions (e.g., "Have you seen Game of Thrones?"), low-level tactics ("If you attack Armenia, I support you"), and high-level strategies ("We must control Central Europe"). The content of these messages is the subject of our study. Due to the centrality of language to diplomacy, we can learn the rhetorical and social tools with which players build and break trust. As this language is embedded in each game, it has practical properties: similar situations are repeated, the goals are clear, and machine-readable commands confirm which players are enemies and which friends. In the next section, we examine the diplomatic data.

sections.heading: 2.3 Preprocessing
sections.text: We use games from two popular online platforms to play Diplomacy.3 The average season of an online diplomacy game lasts nine days. We remove non-standard games caused by differences between the two platforms, as well as games that are still in progress. In addition, we filter setup messages, regulatory messages to and from the game administrator, as well as messages explaining the state of the game, and only keep messages between players. This leaves 249 games with a total of 145,000 messages. The record confirms that communication is an essential part of diplomacy: in half of the games, over 515 messages are exchanged between players, while the top quartile contains over 750 messages per game. Even non-trivial messages (with at least one sentence) tend to be complex: over half of them have at least five sentences, and the top quartile consists of messages with eight or more sentences.

sections.heading: 4 Language Foretelling Betrayal
sections.text: In this section, we examine whether the conversations between two allies of diplomacy contain linguistic clues that predict whether their friendship will endure or end in betrayal. We expect these clues to be subtle, since we consider messages exchanged between the two individuals to be superficially friendly only when at least one of them - the eventual victim - is unaware of the fate of the relationship.

sections.heading: 4.1 What Constitutes a Betrayal
sections.text: To find betrayal, we must first find friendships. Building on the discussion in Section 3, we consider a friendship stable if it is persistent, established and reciprocal. Therefore, we focus on relationships that include at least two consecutive and reciprocal friendships that include at least three seasons in the season. We also verify that no more than five seasons pass between two friendships, because friendships can fade. Betrayal develops and reciprocal friendships that end with at least two hostile acts. sections.heading: 4.3 Predictive Power
sections.text: To test whether these linguistic keywords have any predictive power and to explore how they interact, we automatically turn to a binary classification setting, in which we try to detect whether a player V is betrayed by a player B. (We will refer to player V as a potential victim and player B as a potential traitor.) Expert people - the actual victims - performed poorly in this task and could not say that they are betrayed: due to the way the dataset is constructed, the performance of human players is random. We use the same balanced dataset of matching betrayals and enduring friendships as before, and consider as classification instances all seasons coming from each of the two classes (663 treacherous years and 712 from enduring friendships). As characteristics, we use the keywords described above and summarized in Table 1, which are differentiated by sources: V or B. We use logistic regression according to radio unification.

sections.heading: 6 Relevance Beyond the Game
sections.text: While the discovery of betrayal in an online game is a fun and novel task, our work combines with broader research in mathematical social science. In this section, we describe how our work addresses issues that have been addressed in previous research on alliances, negotiations and relationships. Cooperation and relationship building are an essential component of many activities: completing a group project, starting a business, or forging a new relationship. Each of these topics has been the subject of extensive research to understand what constitutes effective relationships. Jung et al. (2012) show that a balanced working relationship tends to perform better in tasks such as programming couples. Imai and Gelfand (2010) show that understanding cultural norms improves negotiation. While this data is decoded in the laboratory, our "found" data is inexpensive because diplomacy games are fun and inherently anonymized. Romance is a popular and more real phenomenon that helps us understand how relationships arise and dissolve.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusions
sections.text: It is not a task that we expect can be solved with high accuracy, as it would provide a reliable "recipe" for avoiding betrayal in relationships; in this unrealistic scenario, it would be unlikely that betrayal would exist. Although the implications are subtle, they bring new insights into the relationship between linguistic balance and stability in relationships. Although we use a game to develop our methodology, the framework developed here can be extended to a wide range of social interaction. Social dynamics in a collaborative environment can bear striking similarities to those present in war games. For example, in Wikipedia, "editing wars" - where attacks coincide with editing - are common in matters of politics, religion, history and nationality (Kittur et al., 2007). As in diplomacy, Wikipedia editors form alliances, argue and negotiate possible compromises. A challenge for the future is to find reliable linguistic connections.
